RMPDescription: Belews Creek Steam Station RMP - Anhydrous Ammonia

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION



In response to the requirements of Federal EPA, this Risk Management Plan has been developed for the Belews Creek Steam Station (BCSS) located in Belews Creek, NC.  BCSS is owned and operated by Duke Energy.



PLANT AND PROCESS INFORMATION



BCSS operates an anhydrous ammonia system as a component supporting selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of the plant's boiler emissions.  Ammonia vapor (in the presence of the SCR catalyst) reduces NOx compounds to nitrogen and water to reduce the total NOx effluent emitted from the plant.



The anhydrous ammonia system is comprised of six storage tanks - 3 for each plant boiler unit.  Each tank has a water capacity of 60,000 gallons, along with feed pumps and vaporizing equipment.  Each of the six tanks will is administratively controlled such that their individual capacity will not exceed 48,000 gallons, for an aggregate site capacity of 289,000 gallons.  This total quantity of ammonia exceeds threshold quantities which invoke the requirements of the Risk Management regulations.



WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO



BCSS has conducted an offsite consequence analysis as required by regulations, including an extremely unlikely worst-case release scenario (i.e., total release of one of the tanks assuming worst case meteorological conditions).  Results of this worst-case event indicate that offsite receptors could be affected.  



A release represented by this worst-case scenario is extremely unlikely because of the design of the system components and the prevention program that is in place.



EPA chemical release reporting databases, EPA guidance documents, and industry experience suggest that the worst-case release scenario as defined in the RMP regulation is so unlikely that it should not be used as a basis for emergency planning purposes.  A more realistic potential release scenario for emergency planning is presented below.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Within the past five years, BCSS has had no accidental releases that resulted in injuries or property damage.  The plant has maintained an excellent safety record throughout its operating history and has never had any major chemical release that could have had adverse effects on the public.

A minor incident did occur in 2011 where an unloading hose displayed signed of leakage. The operators, following procedures, stopped the unloading process and removed the hose from service.  It was determined that the leak lasted around 30 seconds and less than 8 ounces of ammonia seeped through the hose's layers. No environmental impact or employee exposure occurred.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE



In the event that an ammonia release does occur, BCSS has an emergency response program that coordinates emergency response with the appropriate off-site agencies including the Emergency Planning agencies of Stokes, Rockingham, Forsyth, and Guilford Counties, as well as the Belews Creek Fire Department.  BCSS maintains an emergency response team on-site (24/7) with the appropriate number of members, training, and equipment to actively respond to and take action necessary to secure credible releases of ammonia that might occur.  Additionally, there are a number of emergency operations procedures in place which detail the appropriate emergency actions that would help mitigate the effects of releases.



MAINTAINING A SAFE OPERATION



Duke Energy's Belews Creek

Steam Station will continually work to safely manage the hazards of the ammonia system to protect the communities we serve and the employees, vendors, and visitors at the station.  The Risk Management Program will be maintained to reduce the risk of accidental releases through training, procedures, equipment maintenance, and safe work practices.  Periodically, BCSS will audit the program, review the Process Hazard Analysis, coordinate emergency response organizations, and will update the program as needed to assure safe and efficient control and management of the anhydrous ammonia system.
